EXISTING STRUCTURES
────────────────────────
Resource Depot & Smelting Facility at base position (x=-4.5, y=18.5)
• Wooden Chest at (x=-4.5, y=18.5) serving as central storage.
• Stone Furnace at (x=-3.0, y=19.0) for iron smelting.
• Stone Furnace at (x=-4.0, y=21.0) for copper plate production.
• Burner Inserter at (x=0.5, y=21.5) with drop position at (x=0.5, y=20.5).

Automation Lab & Steam Power System (Integrated System)
• Lab at (x=-7.5, y=18.5) configured for automation research.
• Boiler at (x=-5.5, y=24.0) (flagged with fuel issues).
• Generator (Steam Engine) at (x=-0.5, y=24.5) with power network warnings.
• Offshore Pump at (x=-7.5, y=25.5) operating normally.
• Electricity Group with small electric poles at (x=-0.5, y=11.5), (x=-7.5, y=15.5), (x=-4.5, y=15.5), (x=3.5, y=19.5) and (x=1.5, y=22.5).
• Two PipeGroups forming the fluid network at (x=-10.5, y=16.5) & (x=-12.5, y=18.5) and at (x=-8.5, y=20.5) & (x=-2.5, y=21.5).

Copper Cable Factory at position (x=1.5, y=19.5)
• Assembling Machine at (x=1.5, y=19.5) running the copper-cable recipe.
• Burner Inserter at (x=1.5, y=17.5).
• Input Chest at (x=2.5, y=17.5) for receiving copper plates.
• Output Chest at (x=1.5, y=21.5) for dispatching copper-cable.
• Dedicated Copper Buffer Chest at (x=-5.5, y=21.5) holding copper plates.
• Dedicated Transport Belt Segment at (x=0.5, y=17.5) connecting production outputs.
• Additional Burner Inserters at (x=2.5, y=16.5) and (x=3.5, y=17.5) with defined pickup and drop positions.

Copper Extraction System (adjacent to the copper smelting furnace)
• Extraction Burner Inserter at (x=-3.5, y=23.5) with pickup at (x=-3.5, y=22.5) and drop at (x=-3.5, y=24.5).
• Copper Buffer Chest at (x=-3.5, y=26.5) for extraction storage.
• Chest Extraction Burner Inserter at (x=-3.5, y=27.5) with pickup at (x=-3.5, y=26.5) and drop at (x=-3.5, y=28.5).
• Belt Source Inserter with extraction drop at (x=-3.5, y=25.5).

Extraction Belt Depot at position (x=3.5, y=15.5)
• Wooden Chest at (x=3.5, y=15.5) serving as the belt depot.
• Dedicated Transport Belt Segment at (x=4.5, y=15.5) for copper plate conveyance.
• Depot Burner Inserter at (x=3.5, y=14.5) with pickup at (x=3.5, y=15.5) and drop at (x=3.5, y=13.5).

Belt Connection Target Setup for Copper Extraction
• Extraction Source: Wooden Chest at (x=3.5, y=15.5) (from the Extraction Belt Depot).
• Extraction Inserter: Located at (x=4.5, y=15.5) with pickup at (x=3.5, y=15.5) and drop at (x=5.5, y=15.5).
• New Target Inserter: After initial repositioning attempts and crafting of additional burner-inserters, finally placed at (x=8.5, y=9.5) with pickup at (x=8.5, y=10.5) and drop at (x=8.5, y=8.5).
• Manual Transport Belt Chain: A manually placed sequence of transport belts now connects the extraction inserter drop at (x=5.5, y=15.5) to the new target inserter pickup at (x=8.5, y=10.5). The chain comprises horizontal belt segments (expected at approximately (x=6.5, y=15.5), (x=7.5, y=15.5) and (x=8.5, y=15.5)) and vertical belt segments (expected at (x=8.5, y=14.5), (x=8.5, y=13.5), (x=8.5, y=12.5) and (x=8.5, y=11.5)).

ERROR TIPS
────────────────────────
• Inventory and Dependency
 – Ensure that all required components (e.g., burner-inserters) are present in inventory before placement attempts. Craft missing items proactively to avoid errors such as “No burner_inserter in inventory.”

• Underground and Automated Connection Paths
 – When forming underground belt connections, maintain strict grid alignment and provide an unobstructed, continuous route between start and end points. Repeated “Not a valid path to normalise” errors indicate misalignment or segmentation issues.
 – Breaking connections into segments or using intermediate waypoints requires verifying that each segment adheres to grid constraints and connects directly to its adjacent segment.

• Entity Placement Proximity
 – Verify that the player is within the allowed placement radius for an entity. Errors stating “target position is too far” mean the player must move closer to the intended placement location before attempting to place transport belts or similar entities.

• Sequential Connection Dependencies
 – Confirm that all prerequisite entities (such as target inserters and connection drops) are correctly placed and available before initiating any connection operations. Missing elements can lead to cascading failures in subsequent operations.

• Fallback and Manual Approaches
 – When automated connection methods (underground belt links or fallback transport belt segments) repeatedly fail, consider manual placement. However, ensure that manual operations still respect grid alignment and proximity restrictions for successful placement.

This report integrates the unchanged structures with updated details for the Belt Connection Target Setup for Copper Extraction and highlights refined strategies to mitigate recurrent errors observed in recent execution steps.
